title: The Moon Landing
key_facts: On July 20, 1969, Apollo 11 became the first crewed mission to land on the Moon.
Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin walked on the lunar surface while Michael Collins orbited above.
Marked the peak of the Space Race between the USA and the USSR.
Watched by an estimated 650 million people worldwide.
causes: The Cold War rivalry and desire for technological superiority over the Soviet Union.
President John F. Kennedy's 1961 pledge to land a man on the Moon before the decade ended.
The Soviet Union's early lead in space (Sputnik, Yuri Gagarin) prompting a US response.
outcome: US victory in the Space Race.
Advancement of computer technology, materials science, and telecommunications.
A shift in focus towards orbital space stations and the Space Shuttle program.

figures.name: Neil Armstrong
figures.significance: First human to set foot on the Moon.

figures.name: Buzz Aldrin
figures.significance: Second human to walk on the Moon.

figures.name: Michael Collins
figures.significance: Orbited the Moon alone, enabling the safe return of the crew.

impacts: Demonstrated the immense potential of human engineering and collective effort.
Provided the first view of Earth from another celestial body, fueling the environmental movement.
Left American flags and scientific instruments on the lunar surface.
sources: Brinkley, D. (2019). American Moonshot: John F. Kennedy and the Great Space Race.
